references: Typically, the plasma discharge process can be divided into three distinct phases (i.e., ramp-up, flat-top, and ramp-down phases). However, for the ramp-up phase’s plasma, the relatively low current and the difficulty in calculating the eddy currents in passive conductor structures (such as the vacuum chamber and the first wall) often result in inaccurate shape calculations, weakening the correlation between the coil voltage commands and plasma shape. Therefore, considering that the primary objective of the dynamics model is to capture the complex evolution of the plasma state and ultimately facilitate efficient RL training, model training is exclusively based on data from the ramp-up phase where the plasma current surpasses 100100100 kA and flat-top phase with a duration of at least 500500500 ms. Based on the historical discharge logs of HL-3 across campaigns from 2022 to 2024, after such a meticulous selection procedure, a dataset comprising 832832832 successful discharges has been curated, with a temporal resolution of 111 ms, totaling 1,833,51618335161,833,516 time slices. The categorization of these 832832832 shots by flat-top plasma current is detailed in Table 1.

references:
To train a 111-kHz RL-based control policy, it is essential to build a high-fidelity data-driven dynamics model, which can autoregressively produce accurate predictions for up to 252525 variates.
These predictive variates encompass the plasma current, 666 plasma shape and position parameters, and 181818 channels of feedforward coil currents, which together correspond to a 444444-dimensional indispensable input (Table 2) and support the training of an engineering-reasonable policy for controlling 171717 magnetic coil voltages. In comparison to yielding 100100100 ms-averaged evolution [12], forecasting single-variate tearability [5], or only tuning the total power and torque injected from the neutral beams [36], the significantly higher resolution and a larger number of coupling actuators implies to pose considerable challenges and requires a more comprehensive design.

Acknowledging the importance of the historical plasma state and coil commands, the dynamics model integrates a time series as its input to better capture the plasma evolution towards equilibrium. Specifically, given the 111-kHz control frequency, the model uses a 303030-ms historical dataset for single-step prediction of plasma current, shape and position parameters, as well as the coil currents. A summarized list of the input and output variables of the dynamics model can be found in Table 2. Briefly, this model learns up to 252525 variables related to plasma current, shape, and position, as well as coil current from a 444444-dimensional input, which includes autoregressive predictions of these 252525 variables, 171717 executed coil voltage configurations, the toroidal magnetic field, and loop voltage. In addition, n=30𝑛30n=30 represents the length of the time series, and Δ​t=1Δ𝑡1\Delta{t}=1 ms is the temporal resolution. Notably, as the CS coil is composed of two parallel connected sets of coils, the dimension of coil current (Icsubscript𝐼𝑐I_{c}) equals that of coil voltage (U𝑈U) plus 111.

We utilize a stack of DNNs including a three-layer LSTM network, a self-attention module, and a three-layer fully connected MultiLayer Perceptron (MLP). Specifically, each LSTM layer comprises 128128128 hidden neurons with a dropout rate of 0.20.20.2. For the 303030 consecutive steps’ 444444-dimensional input, as in Table 2, the third LSTM layer produces an intermediate hidden layer output with dimensions of 30×1283012830\times 128. Subsequently, the inner product between each 128128128-length tensor and the last one is computed, followed by a softmax-based normalization operation to scale the values between 00 and 111. These self-attention values serve as attention weights to aggregate the original LSTM outputs as a 128128128-length vector. The integration of a self-attention mechanism into the LSTM allows the assignment of distinctive weights to the intermediate output, rather than placing equal emphasis and neglecting the inter-differences. Fig. 3a validates the effectiveness of this modification. Afterward, the self-attention-processed vector undergoes three MLPs with 128128128, 646464, and 252525 neurons and a ReLU activation function, culminating in the single-step prediction of 252525 variables as specified in Table 2.

To unanimously provide multi-task predictions for 252525 variables, in Table 2, the calibration of relative weights assigned to the predictive losses of individual variables could heavily affect the model performance. Mathematically, for a space 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V} containing 252525 variables, the aggregated loss function given the 444444-dimensional input 𝒙𝒙\boldsymbol{x} shall be a scalar L𝒱​(𝒚𝒱,𝒚^𝒱;𝒙)subscriptL𝒱subscript𝒚𝒱subscript^𝒚𝒱𝒙\mathrm{L}_{\mathcal{V}}\left(\boldsymbol{y}_{\mathcal{V}},\hat{\boldsymbol{y}}_{\mathcal{V}};\boldsymbol{x}\right) computed from 252525 individual loss functions Lv​(yv,y^v;𝒙)subscript𝐿𝑣subscript𝑦𝑣subscript^𝑦𝑣𝒙L_{v}\left(y_{v},\hat{y}_{v};\boldsymbol{x}\right) weighted by cvsubscript𝑐𝑣c_{v}, where yvsubscript𝑦𝑣y_{v} and y^vsubscript^𝑦𝑣\hat{y}_{v} correspond to actual data and model prediction for the variable v∈𝒱𝑣𝒱v\in\mathcal{V}, respectively while 𝒚𝒱subscript𝒚𝒱\boldsymbol{y}_{\mathcal{V}} and 𝒚^𝒱subscript^𝒚𝒱\hat{\boldsymbol{y}}_{\mathcal{V}} denote the concatenation of yvsubscript𝑦𝑣y_{v} and y^vsubscript^𝑦𝑣\hat{y}_{v}, ∀v∈𝒱for-all𝑣𝒱\forall v\in\mathcal{V}.
Due to the discrepancies in distribution and noise among the variables, a straightforward averaging of individual loss functions can adversely impact the model’s accuracy. Meanwhile, manual weight tuning is an arduous and time-intensive effort. Therefore, we utilize an adaptive weight adjustment technique by regarding the loss weight cvsubscript𝑐𝑣c_{v} as a trainable single variate[45]. To prevent the loss weights from taking negative values during the optimization process, which could lead to negative loss values, we also employ a non-negative regularization constraint [44] to enhance the learning robustness. To sum up, the final loss function for training can be calculated as

As illustrated in Fig. 7b and Fig. 9a, the post-experiment replay for shot #669166916691 and shot #669866986698 is calculated using the dynamics model. Specifically, the dynamics model starts to evolve according to the input variables in Table 2, set as practical values at the handover time, as well as the practically executed coil voltage commands, which are generated by RL during on-device deployment. In other words, such a post-experiment replay represents the autoregressive output of the dynamics model, and its closeness to the EFITNN-based diagnostic measurement contributes to verifying the accuracy of the dynamic model.

caption: Table 3
State and action space for RL-based magnetic control.

Name Description
State Space 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} Target and currently observed plasma current, and six shape and position parameters
(141414 dimensions)
Action Space 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} Voltage commands of CS and 888 pairs of PF coils
(171717 dimension)
references: In this study, we utilize RL to control the plasma current (Ipsubscript𝐼𝑝I_{p}) and six shape and position parameters (a𝑎a, κ𝜅\kappa, δlsubscript𝛿𝑙\delta_{l}, δusubscript𝛿𝑢\delta_{u}, R𝑅R, Z𝑍Z), and denote the concatenation of current observations as 𝒐𝒐\boldsymbol{o}. To ensure the integrity and stability of HL-3 plasma discharges, we select the actual waveform of shot #6226, an H-mode discharge with ELMs and a plasma current of 300300300 kA, as the desired target 𝒅𝒅\boldsymbol{d} for control. As shown in Table 3, we consider a 141414-dimensional state 𝒔𝒔\boldsymbol{s} by amalgamating the observations 𝒐𝒐\boldsymbol{o} and desired target 𝒅𝒅\boldsymbol{d}, while the 171717-dimensional action 𝒂𝒂\boldsymbol{a} encompasses voltage commands of 111 CS coil and 161616 PF coils. To ensure control safety and hardware integrity, we impose operational constraints by stipulating that the dynamic rate of change between two consecutive voltage commands must not exceed 202020 V/ms. In other words, for any coil, any voltage command that changes beyond this limit will be clipped to adhere to the safety constraints.
